TL,DR: Fun game with a massive open world and wide variety of vehicles, but its successor is better overall. Worth getting when bundled with Crew Motorfest at a massive discount, plus you get to import your Crew 2 vehicles to Motorfest which is a fantastic move by IVT. 

The game has a ton of vehicles and many, many races to do. Chances are you'll find your favourite cars in here except for Toyotas (thankfully Motorfest has Supras but still no LFA). The handling is more arcade-like compared to Motorfest's more realistic driving physics, and cars handle noticeably differently from each other. There is a "pro settings" option to adjust a vehicle's handling to your liking. I personally don't really care for the planes and boats, I enjoy the driving more but to each their own. Weekly summits give you a reason to return to the game, for better or worse depending on how much you like the live service model.

However, I hate the parts system in this and its successor, it just adds to the grind and detracts from the experience. The weekly summits should be enough for player retention. Farming for the set bonus you want (which is important if you want to platinum summits) is RNG and time-consuming, and you'll have to periodically clear your inventory of all the garbage parts you've obtained. The offline mode in Crew 2 isn't great, it exists as a separate save so any progress made in offline mode will be lost if you decide to overwrite this save later from a more recent online save. The car sounds feel artificial, it's inferior even to older games like NFS Hot Pursuit. There are different genres of music you can switch between in the player but the tracks themselves are boring or annoying, just play your own music.

Overall, it's inferior to Motorfest despite having a larger map but still a fairly fun game on its own merit. Just don't buy at full price.

A friend of mine recommended me The Crew 2 a long time ago, and while I was initially sceptical about the game, it turned out to be one if not my favourite racing game ever. And even made me love the genre despite I was never a fan of racing games.

The best thing of the games is the many disciplines you have and vehicles available for you to drive, from old vehicles such as the classic Porsche cars to the newest ones such as the latest Audi R8. You can use the whole United States to fly, drive, ride your motorbike or sail, visiting every major city and doing every type of competition with your vehicles such as street races, rallying, stunts competitions with your aircrafts or a race on the sea. My only negative point is how sometimes the car's driving feels like a tank, specially crashing, but generally speaking the driving is really well executed. 

For a 2018 game it aged perfectly, with good visuals not only for the interiors and exteriors of the vehicles (which can be really customizable) but for the landscapes and cities of the United States. Sometimes you can just travel without purpouse through the map and enjoy the map.

And about the sound (sound effects and music) is pretty enjoyable, but my only flaw is how generic the music stations sound.

[h1] I PLAY WITHOUT crew, ANY QUESTIONS? [/h1]

Personally, I’d give The Crew 2 a “good” rating (without comparing it to the first one – I never got around to playing it).

TC2 really does have a lot of cool features: planes and boats are finally here, plus a pretty basic progression system.

The map size is seriously impressive – it feels like a mini-America, giving players plenty of space to explore and race around.

But there’s a big problem – the map isn’t filled with interesting spots. What I mean is, there’s a lack of TRULY unique activities and places to discover. Sure, there are cargo delivery missions, but really, it’s just random drives from one random point A to another random point B.

Moreover, the artificial intelligence in the game does not provide a real challenge. On the "Ace" difficulty, it can be somewhat tough, as the AI sometimes behaves incorrectly—simply put, it cheats. Because of this, the player almost always needs to be in first place to avoid losing, which kills the competitive spirit and reduces the satisfaction of victory.

It's hard to say much about online. The tracks are the same as in solo mode, and the modes are not very diverse. And, probably logically, to compete at least somewhat equally with most players online, you need to grind. New cars don't appear very often, so blaming the game for being pay-to-win isn't entirely fair.

Overall, The Crew 2 is an interesting game with good concepts and possibilities, but it lacks content and depth to become a truly memorable project.

And hopefully, the same won't happen with the second installment and Motorfest as it did with the first.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

The Crew 2 tries to be an all-in-one racing experience — cars, boats, planes — but ends up failing at almost everything. The voice acting is bad, customization feels weak, and the UI is clunky. Driving doesn’t feel good either: cornering, turning, and general car handling are terrible, like the vehicles have no weight or traction. Planes and boats somehow manage to feel even worse, with awkward controls and no sense of speed or realism. The game looks decent from far away, but up close the quality sucks, and it all feels shallow.

Overall, The Crew 2 is a huge open world full of things to do — none of which are actually fun.

Such a "meh' game. There are a million problems with it. I'll make a list:

4- There's too much content but barely any depth to them. No one asked for Planes or Boats. Wish it was all cars.
5- The map is great to explore, but sometimes it's so barren. It's got reduced details compared to TC1.

Don’t waste your time and money on this game.

-The cars suffer from stiff handling and feel heavy and unresponsive compared to other games.
-The graphics are mediocre at best and dated at worst.
-The vehicles feel extremely slow due to the lack of visual feedback for speed (ignoring the 
  speedometer). To make things worse, the developers removed the ability to turn off the awful motion 
  blur and TAA (for players like me, for example).
-Activities feel bland and unwarranted at times—like driving a demolition derby car across the country 
  with no real stakes.
-You’re forced to grind for hours to get randomly generated loot to upgrade your car, as if this were an 
  MMORPG or a Borderlands title instead of an arcade racing game.
-There’s no incentive to get better or cooler cars since performance is determined by loot with numbers 
  on it.
-Even the high-end cars suffer from poor control and a lack of speed, feeling like turbocharged bricks of 
  misplaced steel and aluminum.
-The offline mode still requires anti-cheat and for me refused to work when my internet was down (great 
  one Ubisoft :D)
-Final point: the cars have a terrible lack of customization and feel utterly bland.

It’s better to buy a Need for Speed game or find another arcade racing sim (but not Forza Horizon, especially Forza Horizon 5).

The Crew 2 tries to be an all-in-one racing experience — cars, boats, planes — but ends up failing at almost everything. The voice acting is bad, customization feels weak, and the UI is clunky. Driving doesn’t feel good either: cornering, turning, and general car handling are terrible, like the vehicles have no weight or traction. Planes and boats somehow manage to feel even worse, with awkward controls and no sense of speed or realism. The game looks decent from far away, but up close the quality sucks, and it all feels shallow.

Overall, The Crew 2 is a huge open world full of things to do — none of which are actually fun.

the most 5/10 racing game you can think of.
- ubisoft made (bad thing if you're a bit clueless)
- character customization with the worst set of clothes you can imagine and a very limited character selection. so bad i'd probably enjoy the game more if they didn't include it or at least chose to not add some cars in favour of adding more character items. primarily irritating because roughly 1/3 of each clothing category is just hogged up by clothing recolours, with no way of choosing colours for the clothing after you buy it, similar to car interiors or rims.
- "hybrid mode" which is a bit of a shabby attempt at an offline mode. it exists but in of itself it is a 5/10 feature. at least it won't get ripped from you completely like the original crew.
- good car list, but the car pricing is so off that you don't even want to buy cars that you would in any other racing game; for instance, why is an EVO VI 335k and a GTR Nismo is 334k? a stock S2000 is 323k, and a Miura SV is 302k. how do you, for lack of better wording, fuck up pricing that badly?
- very different from the first crew. if it was still 2018 and you had only played the first crew, i'd probably suggest you to not play this because it's like stepping into an earlier version of the current festival racing genre. fun at times but a complete drag for grinding money, xp, or figuring out what on earth you want to do next because everything just feels dull after you've gotten all the cars you want and completed the current "weekly challenge set" and having friends to play it with you doesn't change that
- story. oh god. complete drag, you have a few... noticeable character traits if you feel like turning your playthrough into an observation activity in a psychology degree. just trust me, if you do get it, go to audio right after booting up the game and set the voices slider to 0. saves your ears from the regular, corny, irritating cut-in line that is absolutely pointless and the regular thing you just respond "yes i know that already" or "oh just shut up" to.

tl;dr: 5/10, mid, droning experience that babies you too much and feels a bit like GTAO at points.

Such a "meh' game. There are a million problems with it. I'll make a list:

1- It's locked to 60fps. Such a letdown.
2- The graphics are fine for its time, but the anti-aliasing is horrifyingly bad.
3- The physics feel like it's a mobile game or something. The cars are too grippy, the turns feel inconsistent etc. It's a HUGE downgrade coming from either recent NFS games or Forzas.
4- There's too much content but barely any depth to them. No one asked for Planes or Boats. Wish it was all cars.
5- The map is great to explore, but sometimes it's so barren. It's got reduced details compared to TC1.
6- The CONSTANT notifications and stuff on your screen. GOD. It's like you're in a TV advertisement. The UI is so cluttered. I've spent 13hrs on this game and understand absolutely NOTHING about what I should do and where I should go.
7- The races are meh. Very very basic.
8- The playerbase is pretty dead. Have seen like 3 player cars so far. And found no PVP matches.
I bought this for $1 or $2 when it was on like 99% sale. It's worth just that much. Not more.

I really hope Motorfest is better because I'm planning on getting it during the Winter sale. Hope it doesn't disappoint.

3/10
Don’t waste your time and money on this game.

-The cars suffer from stiff handling and feel heavy and unresponsive compared to other games.
-The graphics are mediocre at best and dated at worst.
-The vehicles feel extremely slow due to the lack of visual feedback for speed (ignoring the 
  speedometer). To make things worse, the developers removed the ability to turn off the awful motion 
  blur and TAA (for players like me, for example).
-Activities feel bland and unwarranted at times—like driving a demolition derby car across the country 
  with no real stakes.
-You’re forced to grind for hours to get randomly generated loot to upgrade your car, as if this were an 
  MMORPG or a Borderlands title instead of an arcade racing game.
-There’s no incentive to get better or cooler cars since performance is determined by loot with numbers 
  on it.
-Even the high-end cars suffer from poor control and a lack of speed, feeling like turbocharged bricks of 
  misplaced steel and aluminum.
-The offline mode still requires anti-cheat and for me refused to work when my internet was down (great 
  one Ubisoft :D)
-Final point: the cars have a terrible lack of customization and feel utterly bland.

It’s better to buy a Need for Speed game or find another arcade racing sim (but not Forza Horizon, especially Forza Horizon 5).
